One of those films is set right here in southern California.
It's called The Garden.
As NPR's Carrie Kahn reports, the film looks at how some poor immigrants battled to save a farm in an unlikely part of Los Angeles.
Shot from a helicopter, the opening scenes of The Garden are amazing.
Fourteen acres of this lush, green oasis, all surrounded by one of the grittiest, concrete-filled areas of South Central Los Angeles.
On the ground, the well-tended plots are filled with trees and food.
Unidentified Man #1: Papaya, si.
Cilantro, bananas.
(Singing in foreign language)
The film, however, moves quickly from green to greed.
Unidentified Man #2: They told me they want us out of the garden.
Just like that.
A group of farmers, almost all poor urban Latino immigrants stand around an eviction notice posted at the gates of the garden they tended for more than a decade.
Filmmaker Scott Kennedy says that's when he started shooting the movie.
There was an eviction notice and a very mysterious eviction notice with a possible backroom deal and shady sale, and the best part was that the farmers weren't leaving.
They're going to stay there, and it just was a story that needed to be told.
That story would take more than four years of Kennedy's life to tell.
He followed the battle with an influential developer who laid claim to the land and documented the farmers' battle with City Hall.
Unidentified Man #3: I'm old now, but I have one little piece of hell to raise and that's around these farmers.

Throughout the protracted struggle and the filmmaker's deft storytelling, alliances shift and ideals are questioned and forsaken.
Kennedy says, he's drawn to stories that challenge America's core principles of justice for all and political transparency.
That's one of the things that I think fascinates me about the story.
How hard it is to maintain that line and what can detract us from that line - greed and self-interest and race and class and all these other things.
This is Kennedy's second featured documentary focusing on one of L.A.'s poor communities but his first to ever get an Oscar nomination.
